content.text: State the speed of the cyclist at time \(= 15 \mathrm{s}\)
Describe the motion of the cyclist
1. from time \(= 0\) to time \(= 5 \mathrm{s}\)
2. from time \(= 10 \mathrm{s}\) to time \(= 20 \mathrm{s}\)
3. from time \(= 20 \mathrm{s}\) to time \(= 30 \mathrm{s}\)
Calculate the distance travelled by the cyclist from time \(= 20 \mathrm{s}\) to time \(= 30 \mathrm{s}\)
distance = .........m
Fig. 1.1 shows the speed–time graph for a cyclist riding a bicycle
Calculate the resultant of the horizontal forces shown in Fig. 2.1
resultant force = .........N
Another person pushes a shopping trolley with a force of \(40\mathrm{N}\). The shopping trolley moves at a constant speed along a horizontal path
Calculate the work done by the \(40\mathrm{N}\) force to move the shopping trolley a distance of \(50\mathrm{m}\)
work done = .........J
The work done on the shopping trolley as it starts moving is transferred into other energy stores
State two such energy stores
In (a), the weight of the pushchair and child is \(240 \text{N}\)
The total area of contact with the ground is \(38 \text{cm}^2\)
Calculate the pressure on the ground due to the pushchair and child
pressure on ground = .........N/cm²
A person pushes a pushchair. A young child rides in the pushchair. Fig. 2.1 shows horizontal forces acting on the front wheel of the pushchair
Describe how the student can find the volume of the piece of metal
In your answer you may refer to some or all of the equipment shown in Fig. 3.1
The mass of another piece of the metal is \(350\mathrm{g}\). The volume of this piece of metal is \(18\mathrm{cm}^3\)
Calculate the density of the metal
A student determines the density of a metal. Fig. 3.1 shows an irregularly shaped piece of the metal and some equipment
State the value of the wasted output energy
wasted output energy = .........J
The energy that is wasted is transferred to an energy store. State the energy store that is increased by the wasted energy
Fig. 4.1 shows the energy transfers in a lamp
A 15W lamp is switched on for 5.0 minutes
Calculate the electrical work done in the lamp circuit during this time
electrical energy supplied = .........J
The lamp uses electrical energy that is generated by a wind turbine
Fig. 4.2 shows a wind turbine
Describe **three** energy transfers that take place when energy from the Sun causes electrical energy to be generated by the wind turbine
Describe the motion, separation and arrangement of the air particles in the metal box
A student puts the box in a freezer. The temperature of the air in the box decreases
Describe the changes in the motion of the air particles in the box when the temperature decreases
Fig. 5.1 shows a metal box. The air in the box is at room temperature, \(20^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Air cannot leave or enter the box
Fig. 5.1
The students hear a loud sound from the firework and then they hear a quieter, similar sound
State what causes the second quieter, similar sound
The time from when the students see the firework burst to when they hear the first, loud sound is 1.3 s
Calculate the distance from the firework to the students
Use the speed of sound in air \(= 340 \text{m / s}\)
distance to firework = .........m
Fig. 6.1 shows some students near some rocky cliffs looking at a boat at sea. The students watch a firework display on the boat. One of the fireworks bursts and makes a loud sound
State the name of the process shown in Fig. 7.1
State the name of the process shown in Fig. 7.2
State the name of the process shown in Fig. 7.3
Give a reason why the waves in Fig. 7.3 change direction as they move from deep water to shallow water
A student demonstrates three different processes that change the direction of water waves in a ripple tank
Fig. 7.1, Fig. 7.2 and Fig. 7.3 illustrate the three processes
Describe the direction of vibration of particles in a transverse wave
Fig. 7.4 lists examples of waves. Two of the examples are transverse waves
Indicate which of the examples are transverse waves
Put a tick \((\checkmark)\) in the box next to each example of a transverse wave
The velocity of a wave is \(1500 \text{m/s}\). The frequency of the wave is \(250 \text{Hz}\)
Calculate the wavelength of the wave
wavelength = .........m
Determine the distance of the image from the centre of the lens. Use information from Fig. 8.1
image distance = .........m
Determine the focal length of the lens. Use information from Fig. 8.1
focal length = .........m
State two characteristics of the image formed by the lens in Fig. 8.1
Fig. 8.1 shows a ray diagram for a thin converging lens
The lens forms an image of the object. The object is positioned \(30\mathrm{cm}\) from the centre of the lens
Complete Fig. 8.2 by writing the name of one type of radiation in each box
State one use of ultraviolet radiation
State one danger to people from excessive exposure to ultraviolet radiation
Fig. 8.2 shows labels for part of the electromagnetic spectrum in order of decreasing wavelength
decreasing wavelength
The student connects a piece of tin metal between X and Y
Describe how the student can determine whether tin is an electrical conductor
Describe electrical conduction in a metal
Use your ideas about electrons in your answer
A student tests various materials to determine whether they are electrical conductors or insulators. The student uses the circuit shown in Fig. 9.1
The current in the electrical heater is 2.2 A. The voltage (p.d.) across the heater is 12 V
Calculate the energy transferred to the heater in 90 s
energy transferred = .........J
The power supply is connected to the electrical mains by a cable that consists of three wires
State the name for each of the three wires in the cable
The power supply includes a transformer

The voltage \((V_{\mathrm{p}})\) across the primary coil of the transformer is \(228\mathrm{V}.\) The voltage \((V_{\mathrm{s}})\) across the secondary coil of the transformer is \(12\mathrm{V}.\) The number of turns on the primary coil \((N_{\mathrm{p}})\) is 760
Calculate the number of turns \((N_{\mathrm{s}})\) on the secondary coil
In an experiment, a student uses an electrical heater connected to a power supply
In Fig. 11.1, there are four labels without the name of the planet
For each label, state the name of the planet
Describe how the planets in the Solar System were formed
Use your ideas about the accretion model. You may draw a diagram as part of your answer
Fig. 11.1 represents the planets in the Solar System
